1714    /**
1715     * Creates a ColorChangeImage Actor that should look like the glyph '^' in this font, but will be rotate-able. The
1716     * ColorChange classes will rotate between all colors given in the List in the given amount of loopTime, and are not
1717     * affected by setColor, though they are affected by their setColors methods. Their color change is not considered
1718     * an animation for the purposes of things like SquidPanel.hasActiveAnimations() .
1719     * @param colors a List of Color to tint the '^' with, looping through all elements in the list each second
1720     * @param loopTime the amount of time, in seconds, to spend looping through all colors in the list
1721     * @return the Actor, with no position set.
1722     */
1723    public Image makeDirectionMarker(Collection<Color> colors, float loopTime, boolean doubleWidth) {
1724        if (!initialized) {
1725            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1726        }
1727        ArrayList<Color> colors2 = null;
1728        if (colors != null && !colors.isEmpty()) {
1729            colors2 = new ArrayList<>(colors.size());
1730            for (Color c : colors) {
1731                colors2.add(scc.filter(c));
1732            }
1733        }
1734        ColorChangeImage im = new ColorChangeImage(dirMarker, loopTime, doubleWidth,
1735                actualCellWidth, actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0), colors2);
1736        im.setAlign(2);
1737        im.setSize(actualCellWidth * (doubleWidth ? 2 : 1), actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0)); //  - lineHeight / actualCellHeight //+ lineTweak * 1f
1738        return im;
1739    }
1740    /**
1741     * Creates a Image Actor that should look like the glyph '^' in this font, but will be rotate-able.
1742     * @param color a Color to tint the '^' with
1743     * @return the Actor, with no position set.
1744     */
1745    public Image makeDirectionMarker(Color color) {
1746        if (!initialized) {
1747            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1748        }
1749        Image im = new Image(dirMarker);
1750        im.setColor(scc.filter(color));
1751        im.setSize(actualCellWidth, actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0)); //  - lineHeight / actualCellHeight //+ lineTweak * 1f
1752        im.setOrigin(1); //center
1753        return im;
1754    }

1756    /**
1757     * Given a char and a Color, makes a ColorChangeImage of that colored char so it can be rotated and so on.
1758     * @param glyph a char; should probably be visible, so not space or tab
1759     * @param color a Color to use for the image; will not change even though ColorChangeImage permits this
1760     * @return the ColorChangeImage with the one color for glyph
1761     */
1762    public ColorChangeImage makeGlyphImage(char glyph, Color color)
1763    {
1764        return makeGlyphImage(glyph, color, false);
1765    }
1766    /**
1767     * Given a char and a Color, makes a ColorChangeImage of that colored char so it can be rotated and so on.
1768     * This overload allows double-width mode to be specified.
1769     * @param glyph a char; should probably be visible, so not space or tab
1770     * @param color a Color to use for the image; will not change even though ColorChangeImage permits this
1771     * @param doubleWidth true if layout uses two chars of width per logical cell, false otherwise
1772     * @return the ColorChangeImage with the one color for glyph
1773     */
1774    public ColorChangeImage makeGlyphImage(char glyph, Color color, boolean doubleWidth)
1775    {
1776        if (!initialized) {
1777            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1778        }
1779        TextureRegion tr;
1780        if (glyphTextures.containsKey(glyph))
1781        {
1782            tr = glyphTextures.get(glyph);
1783        }
1784        else
1785        {
1786            BitmapFont.Glyph g = bmpFont.getData().getGlyph(glyph);
1787            tr = new TextureRegion(bmpFont.getRegion(g.page), g.srcX, g.srcY, g.width, g.height);
1788            glyphTextures.put(glyph, tr);
1789        }
1790
1791        ColorChangeImage im = new ColorChangeImage(tr, 1, doubleWidth,
1792                actualCellWidth, actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0), Maker.makeList(scc.filter(color)));
1793        im.setAlign(2);
1794        im.setSize(actualCellWidth * (doubleWidth ? 2 : 1), actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0)); //  - lineHeight / actualCellHeight //+ lineTweak * 1f
1795        return im;
1796    }
1797    /**
1798     * Given a char and a Collection of Color (such as a List that might be produced by
1799     * {@link SquidColorCenter#gradient(Color, Color)}), makes a ColorChangeImage of that char so it can be rotated and
1800     * so on. The colors will cycle through the given collection onceper {@code loopTime} seconds. You can specify
1801     * double-width mode if you use it, probably in SquidPanel or SquidLayers.
1802     * @param glyph a char; should probably be visible, so not space or tab
1803     * @param colors a Collection of Colors to use for the image; the image will cycle through them in order
1804     * @param loopTime the amount of time, in seconds, it should take for all colors to be cycled through
1805     * @param doubleWidth true if layout uses two chars of width per logical cell, false otherwise
1806     * @return the ColorChangeImage with the one color for glyph
1807     */
1808    public ColorChangeImage makeGlyphImage(char glyph, Collection<Color> colors, float loopTime, boolean doubleWidth) {
1809        if (!initialized) {
1810            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1811        }
1812        TextureRegion tr;
1813        if (glyphTextures.containsKey(glyph))
1814        {
1815            tr = glyphTextures.get(glyph);
1816        }
1817        else
1818        {
1819            BitmapFont.Glyph g = bmpFont.getData().getGlyph(glyph);
1820            tr = new TextureRegion(bmpFont.getRegion(g.page), g.srcX, g.srcY, g.width, g.height);
1821            glyphTextures.put(glyph, tr);
1822        }
1823        ArrayList<Color> colors2 = null;
1824        if (colors != null && !colors.isEmpty()) {
1825            colors2 = new ArrayList<>(colors.size());
1826            for (Color c : colors) {
1827                colors2.add(scc.filter(c));
1828            }
1829        }
1830        ColorChangeImage im = new ColorChangeImage(tr, loopTime, doubleWidth,
1831                actualCellWidth, actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0), colors2);
1832        im.setAlign(2);
1833        im.setSize(actualCellWidth * (doubleWidth ? 2 : 1), actualCellHeight + (distanceField ? 1 : 0)); //  - lineHeight / actualCellHeight //+ lineTweak * 1f
1834        return im;
1835    }

1844    public Actor makeActor(TextureRegion tr, Color color) {

1846            throw new IllegalStateException("This factory has not yet been initialized!");
1847        }
1848        if (tr == null) {
1849            Image im = new Image(block);
1850            im.setColor(scc.filter(color));
1851            im.setSize(width, height);
1852            // im.setPosition(x - width * 0.5f, y - height * 0.5f, Align.center);
1853            return im;
1854        } else {
1855            Image im = new Image(tr);
1856            im.setColor(scc.filter(color));
1857            im.setSize(width, height);
1858            // im.setPosition(x - width * 0.5f, y - height * 0.5f, Align.center);
1859            return im;
1860        }
1861    }

1907     * @return a new Glyph that will use the specified char, color, and position

1915    /**
1916     * Gets a Glyph with the given char to show, color as a packed float, and position as x and y in world coordinates.
1917     * Glyph is a kind of scene2d Actor that uses this TextCellFactory to handle its rendering instead of delegating
1918     * that to the Label class from scene2d.ui.
1919     * @param shown char to show; if this is the char with codepoint 0, then this will show a solid block
1920     * @param encodedColor the encoded color as a float, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
1921     * @param x the x position of the Glyph in world coordinates, as would be passed to draw()
1922     * @param y the y position of the Glyph in world coordinates, as would be passed to draw()

1925    public Glyph glyph(char shown, float encodedColor, float x, float y)

1935        return distanceField;
1936    }

1939        return distanceFieldScaleX;
1940    }
1941    public float getDistanceFieldScaleY() {
1942        return distanceFieldScaleY;

1945    /**
1946     * If this uses a distance field font, the smoothing multiplier affects how crisp or blurry lines are, with higher
1947     * numbers generally resulting in more crisp fonts, but numbers that are too high cause jagged aliasing. This starts
1948     * at 1.2f, usually ({@link DefaultResources} notes when a different value is used).
1949     * @return the current smoothing multiplier as a float, which starts at 1.2f for most fonts
1950     */
1951    public float getSmoothingMultiplier() {
1952        return smoothingMultiplier;
1953    }
1954
1955    /**
1956     * If this uses a distance field font, the smoothing multiplier affects how crisp or blurry lines are, with higher
1957     * numbers generally resulting in more crisp fonts, but numbers that are too high cause jagged aliasing. Before this
1958     * is called, the smoothing multiplier is usually 1.2f; {@link DefaultResources} notes when other values are used.
1959     * @param smoothingMultiplier the new value for the smoothing multiplier as a float; should be fairly close to 1f.
1960     * @return this for chaining
1961     */
1962    public TextCellFactory setSmoothingMultiplier(float smoothingMultiplier) {
1963        this.smoothingMultiplier = smoothingMultiplier;
1964        return this;
1965    }
1966
1967    /**
1968     * If using a distance field font, you MUST call this at some point while the batch has begun, or use code that
1969     * calls it for you (which is now much of SquidLib). A typical point to call it is in the
1970     * "void draw(Batch batch, float parentAlpha)" method or an overriding method for a Scene2D class. You should call
1971     * configureShader rarely, typically only a few times per frame if there are no images to render, and this means the
1972     * logical place to call it is in the outermost Group that contains any SquidPanel objects or other widgets. If you
1973     * have multipleTextCellFactory objects, each one needs to have configureShader called before it is used to draw.
1974     * <br>
1975     * SquidLayers, SparseLayers, SubcellLayers, SquidPanel, TextPanel, and ImageSquidPanel already call
1976     * this method in their draw overrides, so you don't need to call this manually if you use any of those. None of
1977     * those classes change the shader after they set it for their uses, so you may need to set the shader on your Batch
1978     * to null to revert to the default shader if you need to draw full-color art.
1979     * <br>
1980     * If you don't use a distance field font, you don't need to call this, but calling it won't cause problems.
1981     *
1982     * @param batch the Batch, such as a {@link FilterBatch}, to configure to render distance field fonts if necessary.
1983     */
1984    public void configureShader(Batch batch) {
1985        if(initialized)
1986        {
1987            if(msdf)
1988            {
1989                if(!shader.equals(batch.getShader())) 
1990                    batch.setShader(shader);
1991                shader.setUniformf("u_smoothing", 2.1198158f * smoothingMultiplier * bmpFont.getData().scaleX);
1992            }
1993            else if (distanceField) {
1994                if(!shader.equals(batch.getShader()))
1995                    batch.setShader(shader);
1996                shader.setUniformf("u_smoothing", 0.35f / (1.9f * smoothingMultiplier * (bmpFont.getData().scaleX + bmpFont.getData().scaleY)));
1997            }
1998        }
1999    }
2000    /**
2001     * Releases all resources of this object.
2002     */
2003    @Override
2004    public void dispose() {
2005        if(block != null) block.getTexture().dispose();
2006        if(bmpFont != null) bmpFont.dispose();
2007    }

2009    /**
2010     * Gets the descent of this TextCellFactory's BitmapFont, which may be useful for layout outside this class.
2011     * @return the descent of the BitmapFont this object uses
2012     */
2013    public float getDescent() {
2014        return descent;
2015    }
2016
2017    public char getDirectionGlyph() {
2018        return directionGlyph;
2019    }

2021    public TextCellFactory setDirectionGlyph(char directionGlyph) {
2022        this.directionGlyph = directionGlyph;
2023        return this;
2024    }
2025
2026    /**
2027     * Adds a pair of Strings (typically both with length 1) as a replacement pair, so when the find String is requested
2028     * to be drawn, the replace String is used instead. Swaps are used when drawing text in each cell in SquidPanel and
2029     * related classes, so Strings longer than 1 char are effectively disregarded beyond the first char.
2030     * <br>
2031     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2032     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2033     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap("^", ",")} and also
2034     * {@code addSwap(",", ":")}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2035     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2036     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2037     * @param find the requested String that will be changed
2038     * @param replace the replacement String that will be used in place of find
2039     * @return this for chaining
2040     */
2041    public TextCellFactory addSwap(String find, String replace)
2042    {
2043        if(find == null || replace == null || find.isEmpty()  || replace.isEmpty() || find.charAt(0) == 0)
2044            return this;
2045        swap.put(find.charAt(0), replace.charAt(0));
2046        return this;
2047    }
2048
2049    /**
2050     * Adds a pair of chars as a replacement pair, so when the find char is requested to be drawn, the replace char is
2051     * used instead.
2052     * <br>
2053     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2054     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2055     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2056     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2057     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2058     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2059     * @param find the requested char that will be changed (converted to a length-1 String)
2060     * @param replace the replacement char that will be used in place of find (converted to a length-1 String)
2061     * @return this for chaining
2062     */
2063    public TextCellFactory addSwap(char find, char replace)
2064    {
2065        if(find == 0)
2066            return this;
2067        swap.put(find, replace);
2068        return this;
2069    }
2070
2071    /**
2072     * Removes the replacement pair, if present, that searches for the given key, find. Swaps are used when drawing text
2073     * in each cell in SquidPanel and related classes, so Strings longer than 1 char are effectively disregarded beyond
2074     * the first char.
2075     * <br>
2076     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2077     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2078     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2079     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2080     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2081     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2082     * @param find the String that would be changed in the replacement pair
2083     * @return this for chaining
2084     */
2085    public TextCellFactory removeSwap(String find)
2086    {
2087
2088        if(find != null && !find.isEmpty() && find.charAt(0) != 0)
2089            swap.remove(find.charAt(0));
2090        return this;
2091    }
2092
2093    /**
2094     * Removes the replacement pair, if present, that searches for the given key, find.
2095     * <br>
2096     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2097     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2098     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2099     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2100     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2101     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2102     * @return this for chaining
2103     */
2104    public TextCellFactory removeSwap(char find)
2105    {
2106        swap.remove(find);
2107        return this;
2108    }
2109
2110    /**
2111     * Gets the current mapping of "swaps", or replacement pairs, to replace keys requested for drawing with their
2112     * values in the {@link CharCharMap}. CharCharMap is a class from RegExodus (a dependency of squidlib-util that is
2113     * used for text matching and Unicode support), which is used here to avoid making yet another primitive-backed
2114     * collection class.
2115     * <br>
2116     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2117     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2118     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2119     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2120     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2121     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2122     * @return the mapping of replacement pairs
2123     */
2124    public CharCharMap getAllSwaps() {
2125        return swap;
2126    }
2127
2128    /**
2129     * Sets the mapping of replacement pairs to a different one as a Map of Character keys to String values.
2130     * <br>
2131     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2132     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2133     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2134     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2135     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2136     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2137     * @param swaps the Map of replacement pairs; keys requested for drawing will be replaced with their values
2138     * @return this for chaining
2139     */
2140    public TextCellFactory setAllSwaps(OrderedMap<Character, Character> swaps) {
2141        swap.clear();
2142        for (int i = 0; i < swaps.size(); i++) {
2143            if(!swaps.keyAt(i).equals('\0'))
2144                swap.put(swaps.keyAt(i), swaps.getAt(i));
2145        }
2146        return this;
2147    }
2148
2149    /**
2150     * Appends to the mapping of replacement pairs, adding or replacing any entries in the current mapping with the
2151     * entries in a Map of Character keys to String values.
2152     * <br>
2153     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2154     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2155     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2156     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2157     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2158     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2159     * @param swaps the Map of replacement pairs to add; keys requested for drawing will be replaced with their values
2160     * @return this for chaining
2161     */
2162    public TextCellFactory addSwaps(OrderedMap<Character, Character> swaps) {
2163        for (int i = 0; i < swaps.size(); i++) {
2164            if(!swaps.keyAt(i).equals('\0'))
2165                swap.put(swaps.keyAt(i), swaps.getAt(i));
2166        }
2167        return this;
2168    }
2169
2170    /**
2171     * Clears all replacement pairs this has been told to swap.
2172     * <br>
2173     * This can be useful when you want to use certain defaults in squidlib-util's dungeon generation, like '~' for deep
2174     * water, but not others, like ',' for shallow water, and would rather have a glyph of your choice replace something
2175     * that would be drawn. Replacements will not be chained; that is, if you {@code addSwap('^', ',')} and also
2176     * {@code addSwap(',', ':')}, then a requested '^' will be drawn as ',', not ':', but a requested ',' will be drawn
2177     * as ':' (only one swap will be performed). Typically you want a different TextCellFactory for UI elements that use
2178     * swapping, like a top-down char-based map, and elements that should not, like those that display normal text.
2179     * @return this for chaining
2180     */
2181    public TextCellFactory clearSwaps()
2182    {
2183        swap.clear();
2184        return this;
2185    }
2186
2187    /**
2188     * Not implemented in this class; in subclasses that do, this should change the currently-used font style, such as
2189     * from regular to italic or bold. Calling this method on a TextCellFactory does nothing, but won't cause problems.
2190     * @param style an int, typically a constant in a class that implements this, that determines what style to use.
2191     */
2192    public void setStyle(int style)
2193    {
2194    }
2195
2196    /**
2197     * A kind of Actor for one char (with one color) that is innately drawn with a specific TextCellFactory, and will
2198     * match the layout behavior of that TextCellFactory when it is used for other purposes. This is an inner class of
2199     * TextCellFactory, and can't be constructed without a TextCellFactory being involved; usually you instantiate
2200     * Glyphs with {@link #glyph(char, Color, float, float)} or an overload of that method on TextCellFactory.
2201     */
2202    public class Glyph extends Actor implements ICellVisible
2203    {
2204        /**
2205         * The char that will be shown for this Glyph.
2206         */
2207        public char shown;
2208        
2209        @Override
2210        public char getSymbol()
2211        {
2212            return shown;
2213        }
2214
2215        /**
2216         * Makes an orange '@' Glyph at 0,0 in world coordinates.
2217         */
2218        public Glyph() {
2219            this('@', SColor.SAFETY_ORANGE, 0f, 0f);
2220        }
2221
2222        /**
2223         * Makes a Glyph of the given char in the given Color, at the specified world coordinates.
2224         * @param shown the char to show
2225         * @param color the Color to use; if null this will instead use {@link SColor#TRANSPARENT}
2226         * @param x x position in world coordinates
2227         * @param y y position in world coordinates
2228         */
2229        public Glyph(char shown, Color color, float x, float y)
2230        {
2231            super();
2232            this.shown = shown;
2233            super.getColor().set(color == null ? SColor.TRANSPARENT : color);
2234            setPosition(x, y);
2235        }
2236
2237        /**
2238         * Makes a Glyph of the given char in the given packed float color, at the specified world coordinates.
2239         * @param shown the char to show
2240         * @param color the packed float color to use, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
2241         * @param x x position in world coordinates
2242         * @param y y position in world coordinates
2243         */
2244        public Glyph(char shown, float color, float x, float y) {
2245            super();
2246            this.shown = shown;
2247            Color.abgr8888ToColor(super.getColor(), color);
2248            setPosition(x, y);
2249        }
2250
2251        /**
2252         * Gets the color of this Glyph as a packed float color; does not allocate any objects.
2253         * @return the color of this Glyph as a packed float
2254         */
2255        @Override
2256        public float getPackedColor() {
2257            return getColor().toFloatBits();
2258        }
2259
2260        /**
2261         * Sets the color of this Glyph with the given packed float color; does not allocate any objects.
2262         * @param color the color to set this Glyph to, as a packed float
2263         */
2264        public void setPackedColor(float color) {
2265            Color.abgr8888ToColor(super.getColor(), color);
2266        }
2267
2268        @Override
2269        public String toString() {
2270            return "Glyph{'" +
2271                    + shown +
2272                    "' with color " + getColor() +
2273                    ", position (" + getX() +
2274                    "," + getY() +
2275                    ")}";
2276        }
2277
2278        /**
2279         * Draws the actor. The batch is configured to draw in the parent's coordinate system.
2280         * {@link Batch#begin()} must have already been called on the batch before this method.
2281         *
2282         * @param batch the batch should be between begin() and end(), usually handled by Stage
2283         * @param parentAlpha Multiplied with this Glyph's alpha, allowing a parent's alpha to affect all children.
2284         */
2285        @Override
2286        public void draw(Batch batch, float parentAlpha) {
2287            TextCellFactory.this.draw(batch, shown, SColor.multiplyAlpha(getColor(), parentAlpha), getX(), getY() + 1);
2288        }
2289    }
2290}
